docs.snippet: For nearly three years, Caterpillar Inc. has been banging its head against the Clinton Administration door, trying to get Government-sponsored loans for the sale of its big earthmovers to China. Beijing is buying them by the dozens to build the giant...
docs.lead_paragraph: For nearly three years, Caterpillar Inc. has been banging its head against the Clinton Administration door, trying to get Government-sponsored loans for the sale of its big earthmovers to China. Beijing is buying them by the dozens to build the giant Three Gorges Dam, which the Administration considers damaging to the environment. So the Chinese have turned to suppliers in Japan and Europe, where governments are less concerned about the environment and more forthcoming with credit. ''We've only managed to sell the Chinese a few off-highway trucks,'' a Caterpillar official said.
docs.abstract: Process of economic globalization is still in early stage as nationality still binds most multinational companies to home; proliferation of treaty negotiations in recent months, aimed at setting rules for global economy--most of them favorable so far to business--has raised new new questions: just how untethered are these companies and who, therefore, should have voice in rule-making? 12 different rule-making negotiations are currently under way; most are inspired by North American Free Trade Agreement and treaty that set up World Trade Organization, in which US and 116 other nations agreed essentially to recognize WTO ruling as having power of national law; for all their involvement in overseas sales and investment, multinational companies like Caterpillar Inc in America, Mitsubishi Corp in Japan or Volkswagen in Germany are still tied to regulations and laws of their countries; graph; drawing (L)

headline.main: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS -- Global Tug, National Tether; As Companies Look Overseas, Governments Hold the Strings

docs.snippet: The $66 million man began his strategic descent into invisibility in late February, and by now it seems complete.    He left his job, left his apartment, left his cars, left his belongings, left everything about his high-octane existence. Even with...
docs.lead_paragraph: The $66 million man began his strategic descent into invisibility in late February, and by now it seems complete. He left his job, left his apartment, left his cars, left his belongings, left everything about his high-octane existence. Even with the F.B.I. chasing him, the authorities admit, he could be almost anywhere, a fully enrolled member of the sludgy world of the fugitive.
docs.abstract: FBI is searching for Ricardo S Carrasco, 42-year-old loan officer with New York office of BankBoston, who vanished on Feb 19 with $66 million that had been fraudulently lent out of New York office; Carasco is from Montevideo, Uruguay, and worked in United States on a visa; case reviewed; photo (M)

headline.main: Missing: One Banker and $66 Million; Trail Grows Cold as F.B.I. Hunts for Loan Officer With a Zest for Living

docs.snippet: On the sprawling plains of Uruguay, where sheep and cattle far outnumber people, the milkman still makes home deliveries by horse and buggy. Elementary school children  wear dour uniforms of the same style their grandparents wore. People still turn...
docs.lead_paragraph: On the sprawling plains of Uruguay, where sheep and cattle far outnumber people, the milkman still makes home deliveries by horse and buggy. Elementary school children wear dour uniforms of the same style their grandparents wore. People still turn to radio more than television for the news, and a national hobby is collecting classic jalopies. So perhaps it is not surprising that the winds of economic change sweeping across almost every corner of Latin America fade to a gentle breeze once they cross the Plata River into Uruguay.
docs.abstract: Economic change sweeping Latin America has largely bypassed Uruguay, where welfare state faces biggest test in years, union-sponsored plebiscite opposing new law to let private companies compete with Government's electric monopoly; unions seek to make Pres Julio Maria Sanguinetti, centrist who pushed law through Congress, into lame duck and propel socialist to presidency next year; map; photo (M)

headline.main: The Welfare State Is Alive, if Besieged, in Uruguay

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL 3-20    European Nations Accept Currency Despite Snag  Eleven European nations approved a plan to begin a common currency, and after bitter disagreements selected Wim F. Duisenberg of the Netherlands as president of the new European...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-20 European Nations Accept Currency Despite Snag Eleven European nations approved a plan to begin a common currency, and after bitter disagreements selected Wim F. Duisenberg of the Netherlands as president of the new European central bank for half of the eight-year term, when he will be succeeded by a French banker. 1

docs.snippet: The computer distributor CHS Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire three computer-equipment distribution businesses in Latin America for cash and stock. The Miami-based CHS said the purchase price would be based on the...
docs.lead_paragraph: The computer distributor CHS Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire three computer-equipment distribution businesses in Latin America for cash and stock. The Miami-based CHS said the purchase price would be based on the acquired businesses' future performance. The companies to be acquired have estimated combined 1998 sales of $330 million. The largest of them is Intcomex, which has annual sales of more than $200 million and operations in Chile, Guatemala, Mexico, Panama, Peru, Uruguay and Miami. CHS will also acquire Acron S.A. of Argentina, with sales of $32 million, and Cornejo Informatica S.A. of Argentina, with sales of $21 million. CHS distributes computers, peripherals and software.
docs.abstract: CHS Electronics Inc to acquire Intcomex, Acron SA and Cornejo Informatica SA, computer-equipment distribution businesses in Latin America, for cash and stock (S)

headline.main: CHS ELECTRONICS IN LATIN AMERICA COMPUTER DEAL

docs.snippet: For many New Yorkers, Jose Marti is just the name on a bronze statue near Central Park South -- a man on a horse clutching his chest with his right hand. Mortally wounded in battle, he is looking down, lips parted in agony or shock.    For Cubans,...
docs.lead_paragraph: For many New Yorkers, Jose Marti is just the name on a bronze statue near Central Park South -- a man on a horse clutching his chest with his right hand. Mortally wounded in battle, he is looking down, lips parted in agony or shock. For Cubans, though, he is the embodiment of all things good -- a poet and a thinker who died at 42 in May 1895, fighting in the Cuban War of Independence against Spain. It all happened a long time ago, but much of it happened in New York City. For it was here that Marti lived 15 years in exile, after the Spaniards deported him from Cuba for his revolutionary ideas.
docs.abstract: Small group of Cubans sets out in self-guided tour to retrace steps of Jose Marti, who lived in New York City in exile from January 1880 to January 1895; photo (M)

headline.main: Retracing a Cuban Patriot's Path Through His Productive Exile

docs.snippet: In his nearly nine years in office, President Carlos Saul Menem has subdued 4,000 percent inflation, calmed mobs, cut the military's budget and slashed the Government bureaucracy.     Now, as the worst flooding this century has spread across...
docs.lead_paragraph: In his nearly nine years in office, President Carlos Saul Menem has subdued 4,000 percent inflation, calmed mobs, cut the military's budget and slashed the Government bureaucracy. Now, as the worst flooding this century has spread across Argentina, Mr. Menem is again seeing opportunity in adversity.
docs.abstract: Flooding in Argentina caused by El Nino has forced 100,000 people from their homes and caused more than $1.5 billion in damage since it began in Apr; Pres Carlos Saul Menem has seized opportunity to spur flagging popularity, traveling to many stricken areas to buoy his image as take-charge leader; his backers seek Constitutional change to allow him to run for third term; photo (M)

headline.main: Floods Giving Argentine President a Political Lift

docs.snippet: David Regis was a citizen of France and is a professional soccer player in Germany. He speaks little English, has been to the United States only three or four times and has trained for only a week with the American soccer team as it prepares for the...
docs.lead_paragraph: David Regis was a citizen of France and is a professional soccer player in Germany. He speaks little English, has been to the United States only three or four times and has trained for only a week with the American soccer team as it prepares for the coming World Cup in France. Yet, today, he passed his exam for American citizenship and was sworn in, just in time to play in an exhibition match here against Kuwait on Sunday.
docs.abstract: David Regis, citizen of France and professional soccer player in Germany, passes his exam for American citizenship and is sworn in just in time to play for American soccer team as it prepares for World Cup in France; photo (M)

headline.main: SOCCER: They All Come to Play for America; Regis Is the Newest Citizen on Polyglot U.S. World Cup Soccer Team

docs.snippet: The American national team made the transcontinental trip from Portland, Ore., to Washington yesterday to prepare for its final domestic tuneup before next month's World Cup finals in France.     The United States (6-3-2 in international matches this...
docs.lead_paragraph: The American national team made the transcontinental trip from Portland, Ore., to Washington yesterday to prepare for its final domestic tuneup before next month's World Cup finals in France. The United States (6-3-2 in international matches this year) will play Scotland on Saturday at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium. Both teams were in action last weekend: the United States toyed with Kuwait in winning by 2-0, and Scotland played a 2-2 tie against Colombia at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.
docs.abstract: US will play Scotland at Robert F Kennedy Stadium in Washington, DC, on May 31 in final tuneup before World Cup finals in France in June (M)

headline.main: One More Tuneup Before World Cup
